repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.abstract: Collection contains correspondence, reports, photographs, articles, flyers, and court documents. The material dates from 1971-86. The collection includes material typical of an organization especially one involved with promoting itself and the issues it found most compelling. A good portion of the material in this collection appear to have served as publicity for the work done by the Community for Creative Non-violence (CCNV) including newspaper articles about the group and form letters they wrote that were probably used for mass mailings.

prefercite.head: Preferred citation
prefercite.p: Mary Ellen Hombs papers, Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Mary Ellen Hombs donated this collection in 1995.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Note
bioghist.p: The materials within the collection relate to the work of the Community for Creative Non-Violence (CCNV) of which Mary Ellen Hombs was a member. From the early 1970s to the early 1990s, CCNV was a major force in the movement to protect the rights of homeless people in Washington D.C. Currently, the CCNV runs a homeless shelter in the city and is very involved in providing food, shelter, and educational opportunities for the poor and homeless in the city.

In a 1981 Washington Post article Mary Ellen Hombs stated her goal as a member of CCVN as wanting to " . . . persuade the churches and the District government to provide shelters in every area of the city, shelters attractive enough 'so that even the most isolated, the most hardened person could feel the desire to come out of the cold". These records give researchers a detailed introduction to CCNV actions especially the non-violent social protest tactics specifically hunger strikes, marches, and sit-ins used by CCNV to present their message to the public.

Founded in the early 1970s by Father Ed Guinan and a group of George Washington University students, CCNV was an activist organization opposed to the Vietnam War. As the war ended, the group began focusing its efforts on the needs of the poor and homeless in the D.C. community. Specifically in 1972, CCNV opened a drop-in center that served meals to homeless people. CCNV quickly followed this meal service with a free medical clinic, a hospitality house for people awaiting trial, and eventually an overnight shelter.

By 1976, CCNV had taken on the dual role of providing shelter for the homeless and making the Washington homeless more visible. They became well known for acts of civil disobedience meant to draw attention to the issue of homelessness in Washington, D.C. For example, in 1981, CCNV erected a tent village in Lafayette Park that they named Reaganville. The tents were meant to symbolize the plight of the homeless in the city. CCNV also erected a symbolic graveyard with 45 white crosses for each of the 45 street people who had died in Washington in the previous five years. Mitch Snyder is perhaps the most well known member of CCNV. His acts of civil disobedience, including several hunger strikes, garnered publicity. He was the subject of a television movie in 1986 staring Martin Sheen. After his death in 1990, the Community for Creative Non-Violence held less protests and focused more on the running of its shelter. The current CCNV mission is " . . . to ensure that the rights of the homeless and poor are not infringed upon and that every person has access to life's basic essentials-food, shelter, clothing and medical care." Today CCNV provides shelter, food, clothing, medical care, and educational support for up to 2,500 people per day in Washington D.C.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection contains correspondence, reports, photographs, articles, flyers, and court documents. The material dates from 1971-86. The collection includes material typical of an organization, especially one involved with promoting itself and the issues it found most compelling. A good portion of the material in this collection appears to have served as publicity for the work done by the Community for Creative Non-violence (CCNV), including newspaper articles about the group and form letters that may have been used for mass mailings. The material relates to specific topics and can provide a look what types of issues the organization dealt with, including those dealing with food and its procurement for the shelter and also the condition of the different shelters in the city. The people most closely associated with CCNV is Mitch Snyder and Carol Fennelly.

arrangement.head: Collection Organization
arrangement.p: Organized into nine series: Conference, Correspondence, Court cases, Ephemera, Graphics, Publications, Publicity, Speeches and statements, and Subjects.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This finding aid was revised in 2022 to address harmful descriptive language. During that revision staff edited the description in the Collection Biographical/Historical Note and the Scope and Contents Note. To see the description prior to revisions, please view the previous version of the Mary Ellen Hombs papers finding aid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Material in this series relates to several conferences about homelessness and poverty. One of the conferences was held at The George Washington University. The material in this series covers the dates 1983-86.

did.unittitle: George Washington University Conference on Homelessness, Nowhere To Go
National Association of Social Workers Professional Symposium, Celebrating the Future

Santa Clara Conference on The Bishops' Pastoral Letter on Catholic Social Teaching and the U.S. Economy Diana Pearce presented the paper Changing Poverty: Comments on Women and Minorities in the Bishops' Letter
APA Annual Convention Symposium, Homelessness: Is it a mental problem?, Mitch Snyder was a discussant

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The correspondence in this series is divided between those sent to CCNV and those sent by CCNV. The letters sent by CCNV are often form letters probably meant to inform potential donors and volunteers of CCNV's latest efforts on behalf of the homeless. The dates covered in this series are 1976-86.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains two court cases including an unlawful entry case brought by the United States against Mary Ellen Hombs, Mitch Snyder, and Harold Moss, all CCNV members, and a separate case against Barry J. Todd. The material covers the years 1982-83.

did.unittitle: Mitchell Snyder, Harold Moss, and Mary Ellen Hombs v. United States. regarding unlawful entry arrest
United States v. Barry J. Todd September

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes a small yellow cloth bag with the statement "Strictly for Da Boids" on the front and "Hee Hee Hee" on the back.

did.unittitle: Small yellow cloth bag with the words, Strictly for Da Boids, on the front and, Hee Hee Hee, on the back.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of two photograph albums. The material covers the dates 1984-86. One album has images related to several different protests including marches and rallies. The other album specifically documents the condition of the Federal City Shelter prior to renovation, the protest march organized when President Reagan did not follow through with his pledged renovation plans, and finally images of start of the renovation including architectural drawings.

did.unittitle: Photograph album: D.C. Shelter existing conditions, protest, demolition, and renovation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series is divided by type of publication and includes the book "Homelessness in America: A Forced March to Nowhere written by Mary Ellen Hombs and Mitch Snyder, magazines, newsletters, and newspaper articles. The newspaper articles relay useful information about the actions taken directly by CCNV. This material covers the years 1971-86.

did.unittitle: Homelessness in America: A Forced March to Nowhere by Mary Ellen Hombs and Mitch Snyder 1982, Advertising for the book
Homelessness in America: A Forced March to Nowhere by Mary Ellen Hombs and Mitch Snyder 1982, Copyright application
Homelessness in America: A Forced March to Nowhere by Mary Ellen Hombs and Mitch Snyder 1982, Edited introduction written by Daniel Berrigan. Edited by Mark (no last name given)
Homelessness in America: A Forced March to Nowhere by Mary Ellen Hombs and Mitch Snyder 1982, Publisher rejection letters
Homelessness in America: A Forced March to Nowhere by Mary Ellen Hombs and Mitch Snyder 1982, Reviews
General Publications, Information: from the National Trust for Historic Preservation: Rehabilitating Residential Hotels
General Publications, Jobswatch produced by the Center for National Policy Review
Magazine articles by Mary Ellen Hombs and Mitch Snyder
Magazine articles, Mental health articles gathered for research by Mary Ellen Hombs
Magazine articles, Village Voice Body Count (HUD)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains the brochures, leaflets, press releases, and public service announcements produced by CCNV and used to spread their message about advocacy for the homeless. The material covers the dates 1976-83.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes speeches and statements by CCNV members Lin, Mary Ellen Hombs, and by Robert M. Hays, Counsel, National Coalition for the Homeless. In addition, series nine, has a file for oral testimony given by CCNV members to the House District Committee, September 30, 1980. The material within this series dates from 1982-86.

did.unittitle: Speeches and Statements, Robert M. Hays remarks before the National Conference on Social Welfare Boston, MA
Speeches and Statements, Robert M. Hays, Counsel, National Coalition for the Homeless statement about Anacostia
Speeches and Statements, Mary Ellen Hombs comments Lancaster, PA
Speeches and Statements, Lin's testimony on the budget
Speeches and Statements, The People's State of the Union Address n.d. and no author

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes documents related to many different issues addressed by CCNV during their work for the homeless in Washington D.C. The dates cover 1976-85. The topics include among others salvaged food, deinstitutionalization, housing information for the CCNV property at 1361 Fairmont St., and information about various shelters in Washington, D.C.
